top_categories.workout_context: RADL GRVL rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
RADL GRVL’s adelaide hills gravel (85%), dirt roads (15%) demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing RADL GRVL isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at RADL GRVL when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of RADL GRVL. Make this intensity feel like home.
At 81 miles, RADL GRVL punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
RADL GRVL’s 8,202ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
RADL GRVL’s adelaide hills—rolling australian bush gravel and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at RADL GRVL — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at RADL GRVL — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on adelaide hills—rolling australian bush gravel.
Low-cadence force work builds the muscular strength for RADL GRVL’s 8,202ft of climbing — especially the grinding, low-speed ascents.
The Norwegian double-threshold method builds the sustained power base for RADL GRVL — massive training stimulus without the recovery cost of VO2max work.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for RADL GRVL’s 81 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at RADL GRVL requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on adelaide hills—rolling australian bush gravel to build confidence. Expect: adelaide hills gravel (85%), dirt roads (15%), rolling australian bush.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on TT Threshold, Gravel Specific, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 81 miles of adelaide hills—rolling australian bush gravel in Adelaide Hills, South Australia.
